text:
82-78 Beaver Street, adjoining and east of the S. E. corner of Hanover Street. At the left is an excavation that extends to Pearl Street, tho the latter is not shown.

July 8, 1903

Wurts Brothers

Beaver Street, north side, east from and across Hanover Street, showing the low Brown Bros. and Co. buildings under demolition. Adjoining same is the 25 story Munson S. S. Line Building, a triangular structure at the apex formed by Beaver Street converging with Wall Street. At the left margin is a portion of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, a building subsequently demolished for the 59 story City Bank Farmers Trust Co.
Building.
Views 2 and 3 are down Exchange Place, a before and after demolition view of the aforementioned Brown Bros. Building. To the right here is the Canadian Bank of Commerce again, on the left being the National City
Bank.
Views: 1,2 March 27, 1928
View 3: June 10, 1928
P. L. Sperr

Beaver Street, north side, east from and across Hanover Street, showing the low Brown Bros. and Co. buildings under demolition. Adjoining same is the 25 story Munson S. S. Line Building, a triangular structure at the apex formed by Beaver Street converging with Wall Street. At the left margin is a portion of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, a building subsequently demolished for the 59 story City Bank Farmers Trust Co.
Building.
Views 2 and 3 are down Exchange Place, a before and after demolition view of the aforementioned Brown Bros. Building. To the right here is the Canadian Bank of Commerce again, on the left being the National City
Bank.
Views: 1,2 March 27, 1928
View 3: June 10, 1928
P. L. Sperr

Beaver Street, north side, east from and across Hanover Street, showing the low Brown Bros. and Co. buildings under demolition. Adjoining same is the 25 story Munson S. S. Line Building, a triangular structure at the apex formed by Beaver Street converging with Wall Street. At the left margin is a portion of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, a building subsequently demolished for the 59 story City Bank Farmers Trust Co.
Building.
Views 2 and 3 are down Exchange Place, a before and after demolition view of the aforementioned Brown Bros. Building. To the right here is the Canadian Bank of Commerce again, on the left being the National City
Bank.
Views: 1,2 March 27, 1928
View 3: June 10, 1928
P. L. Sperr

76-78 and 80 Beaver Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Hanover Street, as seen across the site of Brown Bros. & Co. Building. Also shown (background), is the Hanover Square Station of the Second and Third Ave. Elevated Line on Pearl Street.

June 10, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Hanover Street, east side; north from Beaver Street to Exchange Place, showing workmen erecting scaffolding for the demolition of the Brown Bros. & Co. Building, which occupies that block. On the left, appears the National City Bank Building, at the N.W. corner of Exchange Place. March 27, 1928. P. L. Sperr.

(2) A part of the same, showing the Brown Bros. Co. Building in an advanced stage of demolition. This site is now (1937) occupied by the 35-story Wall and Hanover Building. June 10, 1928.

(1) Hanover Street, east side; north from Beaver Street to Exchange Place, showing workmen erecting scaffolding for the demolition of the Brown Bros. & Co. Building, which occupies that block. On the left, appears the National City Bank Building, at the N.W. corner of Exchange Place. March 27, 1928. P. L. Sperr.

(2) A part of the same, showing the Brown Bros. Co. Building in an advanced stage of demolition. This site is now (1937) occupied by the 35-story Wall and Hanover Building. June 10, 1928.

(1)
71 Beaver Street at the N.W. corner of Hanover Street, as seen across demolition from South William Street. August 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a roof on South William Street, showing the continuation of Beaver Street, north side, to Wall Street.

August 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
71 Beaver Street at the N.W. corner of Hanover Street, as seen across demolition from South William Street. August 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a roof on South William Street, showing the continuation of Beaver Street, north side, to Wall Street.

August 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

74-70 Beaver Street, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of Hanover Street, as seen from the N.E. corner of Hanover Street. The view also shows Hanover Street, west side, from and including Beaver to Pearl Streets.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same showing more of No. 70, which is the Coffee Exchange Building.

P. L. Sperr.

September 22, 1929.

(1)

74-70 Beaver Street, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of Hanover Street, as seen from the N.E. corner of Hanover Street. The view also shows Hanover Street, west side, from and including Beaver to Pearl Streets.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same showing more of No. 70, which is the Coffee Exchange Building.

P. L. Sperr.

September 22, 1929.

Hanover Street, north from Beaver to Wall Streets, showing (right), a portion of the Wall and Hanover Buildings on the N.E. corner. Hanover Street at Exchange Place makes a bend in an easterly direction, thereby hiding from view the east side of the street, and exposing the west side, from Exchange Place to Wall Streets, showing the National City Bank Building, occupying that block. A foot bridge can be seen connecting the latter building, with the 35-story Wall and Hanover Buildings.

June 13, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Beaver Street, east from William across Hanover to Pearl Streets, showing the lower portions of the skyscrapers that fill this, the financial district; that on the left is the City Bank, Farmers Trust Company, and on the right, the New York Cotton Exchange.

November 7, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
